title: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features two different but similar designs on each half of the kain panjang. The left side of the kain panjang features bunches of peony blooms interspersed with birds. The right side of the kain panjang features bunches of orchids and roses interspersed with butterflies. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) birds (motifs)

  subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs

  subject_terms_3: Batik Peranakan costumes

  sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  On both halves
 the buketan design
 comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds
 is depicted.  Two different varieties of flowers and background filler motifs are used on each half.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features two different but similar designs on each half of the kain panjang. The left side of the kain panjang features bunches of peony blooms interspersed with birds. The right side of the kain panjang features bunches of orchids and roses interspersed with butterflies. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  On both halves, the buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is depicted.  Two different varieties of flowers and background filler motifs are used on each half.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.
